RT @SkySportsNews: A number of amateur clubs have said they are boycotting an award-winning grassroots football league as a show of support…
RT @ManchesterLaces: A further two clubs have joined our campaign to ask The @FA to immediately review their transgender policy (which was…

The Bells have convened a meeting with fellow clubs on Monday, as they seek a way forward. At least 10 teams say they are either boycotting the 5-a-side league or strongly considering it.

“This is grassroots sport - we should really not have to fight."
https://t.co/MTKKl402DM

The Bells say the language used by the league was misleading. “If they want to continue like this, then they do need to wholly embrace the #LGBTQ+ community. We are often used as tools to entice big sponsors… this league is gaining from that and from us.”
https://t.co/hbnwyAGk96

🗣 Manchester Laces founder @helenfootball: “The FA policy is really outdated. It doesn't take into account that as women, we have the right to make decisions for ourselves… we don't need to be wrapped in cotton wool."

The FA says its trans policy is currently being reviewed. https://t.co/28Y0IuQicD

The Bells corresponded with the relevant county FA, who referred them to the FA’s 2015 trans policy. However, for amateur football, this policy is not said to be mandatory. The Bells are being supported by @ManchesterLaces who are campaigning on this issue
https://t.co/HTVFDDZlpC

In a statement, the Bells said a league official told the team that due to concerns for the welfare of their future opponents, the player - who is trans non-binary - shouldn’t be allowed to play in a "women's league" & told them to take it up with the FA.
https://t.co/u2ciggZgr1

NEW: An award-winning 5-a-side football league for women & non-binary people that says it’s ‘LGBTQI+ friendly’ is losing clubs in a boycott in support of trans & NB players. Camden Bells FC were challenged over a player after their first match last week.
https://t.co/hbnwyAGk96

We watched the news for most of the afternoon before heading up to the ground. It was eerie. You’ll Never Walk Alone felt very poignant that night, of course. Football didn’t matter at all, but also we needed to carry on. The strangest, saddest day.

RT @POTUS: So far this year, hundreds of anti-LGBTQ bills have been introduced in state legislatures – many of them target transgender chil…
@GabyMcKay @Sayers33 Thanks Gaby! 🙏

@joycecook01 @FIFAcom Thanks Joyce, it’s always about the wonderful diverse, football-loving people that the flag represents, and I know exactly how much you respect that and take pride in the responsibility. Appreciate  all you do and the teamwork will get us there! 🙏

🗣 “We know we can only succeed in our mission of ensuring a fully inclusive tournament if we listen to and work with key stakeholders that represent diverse communities” - @joycecook01, @FIFAcom 👏

🏳️‍🌈 A Pride flag says ‘you’re welcome here’ and I’m more encouraged today. (5/5)

For too long, FIFA, UEFA, and many other parts of football haven’t been that great at talking tactics on LGBT+ inclusion and communicating a strong anti-discrimination ethos to all parts of its team, its global family - particularly those nations that prefer not to hear it. (4/5)

Convening a Stakeholder Group isn’t enough; it shouldn’t have taken til 2021 for football’s governing body to publicly mark Pride; and there’ll be difficult days to come, as we’ve seen with UEFA. 

Nevertheless, @fatma_samoura’s statement today stands - it’s about teamwork. (3/5)

Doesn’t need me to point out the incongruence of FIFA raising a #Pride flag when its flagship tournament is awarded to Russia and Qatar. But what’s not well known is that there are #LGBTQ+ people and allies at FIFA working really hard for change (2/5) 

👉 https://t.co/FyHWdFtigG https://t.co/FxAosanw2j

⚽️ We often say in sport that when it comes to inclusion, everyone’s at different stages on the journey - individual, club, even a huge organisation like FIFA with its 211 national football associations, around a third of which are from countries with anti-#LGBTQ+ laws. (1/5) https://t.co/T2bY5BbobS

@ThisIsSamAdams @ryantatkin @SkySportsNews I think when platforms don't respond swiftly or effectively, it encourages others to think they can do it too, and with more people venting online because stadiums are shut, that's snowballed. @sschoey Why it’s so important it goes beyond just an apology. Was the same with the Thom Brennaman incident. Can only be meaningful if those involved are prepared to help in shifting the culture of men’s sport, so people think differently about these words before they even utter them.

@CallumJewell1 If it’s in their policy to do so, which it should be, that’ll be followed. I’m much more interested in the meaningful education opportunity that arises from something like this. These players earn so much money, there’s more that can be achieved here than from a fine.

The Justin Thomas incident is a classic example of how instinctive it still is for some guys in sports to use discriminatory language to express themselves.
